_comment1: More info on template pools can be found here: https://minecraft.gamepedia.com/Custom_world_generation#JSON_format_8
_comment2: Yes, worldgen json files can have comments. Minecraft does 'lenient' parsing of these json files.
_comment3: The template pool to refer to if the entries in 'elements' fails to generate.
_comment4: Here you can list as many nbt files or placed features to spawn.
_comment5: Do note that placed features needs a special element entry stuff.

elements._comment6: How likely out of all the element for this one to be chosen.

element._comment7: The Identifier of the nbt file itself of the structure piece.
element._comment8: Note, this will automatically check into the 'structures' folder for the nbt file.
element._comment9: The final path would look like 'resources/data/mccourse/structures/kaupen_altar.nbt'
element._comment10: The Jigsaw block in the structure will point to side_pool.json to spawn the other half of the house.
element._comment11: Processor JSON files can be used to randomize or replace blocks dynamically. Here, we don't do any of that.
element._comment12: If set to 'terrain_matching', the house would be deformed to fit the change in land.
element._comment13: That's best for roads so lets stay 'rigid' for now.
element._comment14: The kind of element we are spawning. This one is most likely what you want.
element._comment15: There's 'minecraft:legacy_single_pool_element' but that swaps the behavior of
element._comment16: Air and Structure Void in your piece as well as change the attachment mechanism.
element._comment17: It's only for old Vanilla Jigsaw Structures so don't use it. Stick with non-legacy.
